sections.text: Camila Vega: Hi Victoria—Camila Vega here. Thanks for taking a few minutes. I’ll keep this quick. I’m calling because we’ve been helping VP Sales teams reduce end-of-quarter surprises by adding a lightweight sales execution layer on top of Salesforce or HubSpot. It’s called Sales_Accelerator, and it’s focused on forecasting and early warning signals—so teams don’t find out a “commit” deal is actually slipping when it’s too late.
Victoria Herrera: Hi Camila. I’ve got about five minutes. We’re not really looking at new sales tools right now—what exactly is it?

Camila Vega: Totally understood. Sales_Accelerator sits on top of your CRM—so it’s not a rip-and-replace—and it looks at the actual deal signals that predict slippage: stage aging beyond benchmark, inactivity, no upcoming meeting, and things like being single-threaded or having pricing/terms risk. The big value is it proactively alerts reps and managers when a deal is weakening, and it recommends the next best action to stabilize it.
Victoria Herrera: We already do deal reviews and our managers track deal health. Is this basically just another dashboard?

Camila Vega: Fair question—it’s not just a dashboard. The difference is the warning_alerts are proactive and explainable. Instead of someone remembering to check a report, it pushes alerts to Slack, email, or into the CRM when, say, a commit deal has aged too long, has no next meeting on the calendar, and engagement is dropping. Then it suggests a remediation play—like “reconfirm timeline,” “schedule exec alignment,” or “send security pack”—depending on what’s missing.
Victoria Herrera: We don’t use Slack, and we’re pretty careful about notifications. We already have too many systems sending alerts people ignore.

Camila Vega: That’s a common concern. The alerts can be tuned so it’s only the high-impact situations—like commit deals that are actually weakening—rather than everything that’s slightly off. And if Slack isn’t in play, we can route into CRM tasks or a weekly manager digest. The goal is fewer, higher-quality signals so your team focuses on what matters.
Victoria Herrera: I’m still not sure who would own this. I’m not VP Sales—I handle operations, but we’re slammed and not adding more admin work.

Camila Vega: Makes sense. The ops lift is typically low because we leverage what’s already in the CRM—activities, stage timestamps, meeting fields—so you’re not maintaining another spreadsheet process. The use case we see most is VP Sales improving quarter-end accuracy by replacing manual rollups with an explainable forecast that highlights which commit deals are weakening—stage age plus no next meeting plus low engagement—and then running more targeted deal reviews.
Victoria Herrera: We do have manual rollups, but it’s not the biggest pain. And forecasting accuracy… honestly, our leadership cares, but they’re not going to buy something new mid-year.

Camila Vega: Understood. If timing is the blocker, one option is a small pilot focused just on warning signals—no process overhaul. Even within a quarter, it can help prevent avoidable slippage by surfacing issues early, especially on deals that look fine until they don’t.
Victoria Herrera: We’re also in a niche space. Tideglass isn’t a high-volume sales org. Our pipeline is smaller, longer cycles. Tools that work for SaaS don’t always translate.

Camila Vega: That’s helpful context. Sales_Accelerator is more about deal momentum than high volume. Long cycles are exactly where stage aging, inactivity, and “no next meeting” become silent killers. If a deal sits in the same stage with no meeting scheduled, that’s a strong indicator regardless of industry. The system just makes that visible earlier and consistent across reps.
Victoria Herrera: We already have CRM hygiene issues. If meetings aren’t logged perfectly, won’t this just produce false alarms?

Camila Vega: The quality of signals depends on data, yes. In practice, we start with the signals you already trust and can measure reliably. For example: stage age is usually clean. “No upcoming meeting” depends on whether the calendar integration is consistent. We can start with a conservative set so it doesn’t spam people. But if hygiene is a big gap, this might feel noisy at first.
Victoria Herrera: That’s kind of what I’m worried about. Also, we’re in the middle of a CRM cleanup and a territory redesign. I can’t take on another system implementation conversation.

Camila Vega: I hear you. If it helps, because we sit on top of the CRM, the implementation is typically lighter than a core-system change—but it still requires time and attention from ops, and I don’t want to pretend otherwise. Maybe the better question is: is there a concrete forecasting or slippage problem leadership is pushing you to solve right now?
Victoria Herrera: Not urgently. They complain at quarter-end like everyone does, but it’s not at “buy software” level. Our bigger priority is data cleanliness and process consistency.

Camila Vega: That’s fair. Sales_Accelerator can support consistency, but it’s not a magic fix for data cleanliness. If your team is focused on foundation work this quarter, it may be better to revisit once the CRM cleanup is further along—so the alerts and forecasting are more trustworthy from day one.
Victoria Herrera: Yeah, I think that’s right. Also, I’m not the decision maker for new sales tools. I’d have to pull in our VP Sales and I don’t want to do that unless there’s a real initiative.

Camila Vega: Completely reasonable. Would it be helpful if I sent a short one-pager on the warning_alerts concept and the forecasting use case—just so you have it for later if leadership asks about improving commit accuracy?
Victoria Herrera: You can send something, sure. But I can’t promise it’ll get attention right now.
Camila Vega: That’s okay. What’s the best email for you? And if you don’t mind—when would be a better time to re-check in? After your CRM cleanup milestone, or after territory work settles?
Victoria Herrera: Email is victoria.herrera@tideglass… and check back maybe in late Q2. But again, no guarantees.

Camila Vega: Perfect—late Q2 it is. I’ll send a concise overview focused on the two things we discussed: early warning alerts for weakening commit deals—stage aging, inactivity, no next meeting—and how that supports more targeted deal reviews without spreadsheets. Thanks for your time today, Victoria.
Victoria Herrera: Thanks, Camila. Bye.
